title: The chemistry of cookies - Stephanie Warren

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the butter inside the cookie dough when it reaches 92 degrees Fahrenheit?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It melts, causing the dough to start spreading out.

options.label: C
options.text: It evaporates, leaving behind a dry cookie.

options.label: D
options.text: It reacts with the acids in the dough to create carbon dioxide gas.

multiple-choice.question: What is an emulsion, and what are its components in the context of butter?

options.label: A
options.text: An emulsion is a mixture of two substances that want to stay together, in this case, water and fat.

options.label: B
options.text: An emulsion is a mixture of two substances that don't want to stay together, in this case, water and fat.

options.label: C
options.text: An emulsion is a mixture of two substances that are already combined, in this case, water and fat.

options.label: D
options.text: An emulsion is a mixture of two substances that are separate, in this case, water and fat.

options.text: They transform into a different type of bacteria.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To make airy pockets in the cookies.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the Maillard reaction, and what temperature does it occur at?

options.label: A
options.text: The Maillard reaction is a chemical reaction that occurs when proteins and sugars break down and rearrange themselves, forming ring-like structures. It occurs at 212 degrees Fahrenheit.

options.label: B
options.text: The Maillard reaction is a chemical reaction that occurs when proteins and sugars break down and rearrange themselves, forming ring-like structures. It occurs at 310 degrees Fahrenheit.

options.label: C
options.text: The Maillard reaction is a chemical reaction that occurs when proteins and sugars combine and form a new substance. It occurs at 356 degrees Fahrenheit.

options.label: D
options.text: The Maillard reaction is a chemical reaction that occurs when proteins and sugars disappear. It occurs at 390 degrees Fahrenheit.

multiple-choice.question: What is caramelization, and what temperature does it occur at?

options.label: A
options.text: Caramelization is the process of adding sugar to the cookie dough. It occurs at 92 degrees Fahrenheit.

options.label: B
options.text: Caramelization is the process of breaking down sugar molecules under high heat, forming sweet, nutty, and slightly bitter flavor compounds. It occurs at 356 degrees Fahrenheit.

options.label: C
options.text: Caramelization is the process of combining sugar and protein molecules. It occurs at 310 degrees Fahrenheit.

options.label: D
options.text: Caramelization is the process of eliminating sugar molecules. It occurs at 390 degrees Fahrenheit.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ideal temperature for caramelization to occur?
What is a sensitive scientific instrument that can be used to determine when the cookies are ready?
What is the result of the Maillard reaction and caramelization in the cookies?

options.label: A
options.text: A crunchy texture and a dry flavor.

options.label: B
options.text: A light and flaky texture and a sweet flavor.

options.label: C
options.text: A rich brown color and a range of flavor and aroma compounds.

options.label: D
options.text: A dark color and a bitter flavor.

title: All of the energy in the universe is... - George Zaidan and Charles Morton

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of energy that makes it difficult to define?

options.label: B
options.text: Energy is visible to the human eye.

options.label: C
options.text: Energy is not directly observable but its effects can be seen.

options.label: D
options.text: Energy is not related to motion.

multiple-choice.question: Which type of energy is stored in chemical bonds?
What happens to the potential energy stored in a stretched rubber band when it is cut?

options.label: C
options.text: It is converted to kinetic energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is kinetic energy?
How does the temperature of a group of molecules relate to their average kinetic energy?

options.label: A
options.text: Temperature is directly proportional to average kinetic energy.

options.label: B
options.text: Temperature is inversely proportional to average kinetic energy.

options.label: C
options.text: Temperature is unrelated to average kinetic energy.

options.label: D
options.text: Temperature is the same as average kinetic energy.

options.label: B
options.text: The air molecules transfer some of their energy to the molecules in your skin, and you feel heat.

options.label: C
options.text: You and the air molecules do not transfer energy.

options.label: D
options.text: The air molecules have the same energy as your skin.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the temperature of the air and the temperature of your skin on a cold day?

options.label: A
options.text: The air temperature is higher than your skin temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: The air temperature is lower than your skin temperature.

options.label: C
options.text: The air temperature is the same as your skin temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: The air temperature and your skin temperature are unrelated.

options.label: A
options.text: It is stored in the food.

options.label: B
options.text: It is transferred to the air and used to cook the food.

options.label: A
options.text: It is stored in the body and used to maintain life functions.

options.label: B
options.text: It is released into the environment.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept that energy is neither created nor destroyed, but ever shape-shifting?

options.label: A
options.text: The law of conservation of energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the kinetic energy of molecules and their movement?

options.label: A
options.text: The kinetic energy of molecules determines their movement.

options.label: B
options.text: The kinetic energy of molecules is unrelated to their movement.

options.label: C
options.text: The kinetic energy of molecules is a result of their movement.

options.label: D
options.text: The kinetic energy of molecules is the same as their rest energy.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the flow of energy into your skin on a cold day?

options.label: C
options.text: The flow of energy remains the same.

options.label: D
options.text: The flow of energy is unrelated to the temperature.

options.label: A
options.text: The air temperature is higher, and the flow of energy increases.

options.label: B
options.text: The air temperature is lower, and the flow of energy decreases.

options.label: C
options.text: The air temperature is the same, and the flow of energy remains the same.

options.label: D
options.text: The air temperature and the flow of energy are unrelated.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the air reaches your skin temperature on a cold day?

options.label: C
options.text: The flow of energy stops for a brief moment.

options.label: D
options.text: The flow of energy remains the same.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the energy of the universe and the energy of a closed system?

options.label: A
options.text: The energy of the universe is greater than the energy of a closed system.

options.label: B
options.text: The energy of the universe is less than the energy of a closed system.

options.label: C
options.text: The energy of the universe is the same as the energy of a closed system.

options.label: D
options.text: The energy of the universe is neither created nor destroyed, but ever shape-shifting.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept that energy is transferred from one place to another?

options.label: A
options.text: The law of conservation of energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the kinetic energy of molecules and their vibration?

options.label: A
options.text: The kinetic energy of molecules determines their vibration.

options.label: B
options.text: The kinetic energy of molecules is unrelated to their vibration.

options.label: C
options.text: The kinetic energy of molecules is a result of their vibration.

options.label: D
options.text: The kinetic energy of molecules is the same as their rest energy.

multiple-choice.question: 18) What happens to the molecules in the air around you on a hot day?

options.label: C
options.text: They have the same kinetic energy.

title: Kabuki: The people's dramatic art - Amanda Mattes

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the word "Kabuki"?

options.label: A
options.text: From the Japanese word for "Japanese theater"

options.label: B
options.text: From the Japanese verb kabuku, meaning out of the ordinary or bizarre

options.label: C
options.text: From the name of a famous Japanese actor

options.label: D
options.text: From the name of a Japanese dance

multiple-choice.question: In what city did Kabuki originate in the early 17th century?
Who was the shrine maiden who first performed unusual dances on the dry Kamo Riverbed in Kyoto?
What was the main difference between Kabuki and Noh?

options.label: A
options.text: Kabuki used masks, while Noh used makeup

options.label: B
options.text: Kabuki focused on historical events and everyday life, while Noh focused on folk tales

options.label: C
options.text: Kabuki was performed by men, while Noh was performed by women

options.label: D
options.text: Kabuki was a more formal dance form, while Noh was a more informal dance form

multiple-choice.question: Why was Kabuki initially banned by the Tokugawa shogunate in 1629?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to its risqué content and the conservative nature of the Tokugawa shogunate

options.label: B
options.text: Ban on young boys under the age of 15 from performing

options.label: C
options.text: Ban on elaborate costumes and makeup and stage weaponry

multiple-choice.question: What form of puppet theater influenced Kabuki?
What was the main influence on the development of Kabuki before 1868?
Which of the following European artists were inspired by Japanese art and incorporated Kabuki influences in their work?
Who was one of the directors who led to a resurgence of Kabuki after World War II?
What was the result of the U.S. censorship of Japanese traditions during World War II?

options.label: C
options.text: Kabuki was popular amongst American troops stationed in Japan

title: Light waves, visible and invisible

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the speaker's discussion about light?

options.label: A
options.text: Light is a form of electromagnetic radiation that can only be seen by the human eye.

options.label: B
options.text: Light is a form of electromagnetic radiation that acts like both a wave and a particle.

options.label: C
options.text: Light is a form of electromagnetic radiation that is only visible to the human eye.

options.label: D
options.text: Light is a form of electromagnetic radiation that can only be detected by special devices.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the wavelength and frequency of a wave of light?

options.label: A
options.text: Wavelength and frequency are directly proportional to each other.

options.label: B
options.text: Wavelength and frequency are inversely proportional to each other.

options.label: C
options.text: Wavelength and frequency are related in such a way that their product is constant (c = λν).

options.label: D
options.text: Wavelength and frequency are independent of each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between visible light and other forms of electromagnetic radiation?

options.label: A
options.text: Visible light has a higher energy than other forms of electromagnetic radiation.

options.label: B
options.text: Visible light has a lower energy than other forms of electromagnetic radiation.

options.label: C
options.text: Visible light has a different wavelength than other forms of electromagnetic radiation.

options.label: D
options.text: Visible light has a different frequency than other forms of electromagnetic radiation.

multiple-choice.question: How do the rods and cones in the retina of the eye detect light?

options.label: A
options.text: Rods detect brightness and cones detect color.

options.label: B
options.text: Rods detect color and cones detect brightness.

options.label: C
options.text: Rods and cones detect both brightness and color.

options.label: D
options.text: Rods and cones do not detect light.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Hubble Space Telescope?

options.label: B
options.text: To study the universe in visible and ultraviolet light.

multiple-choice.question: How many space telescopes are in orbit, each seeing part of the full spectrum of light?
What is the relationship between the energy of light and its interaction with matter?

options.label: A
options.text: The energy of light determines the type of matter it interacts with.

options.label: B
options.text: The energy of light determines the amount of matter it interacts with.

options.label: C
options.text: The energy of light determines how it interacts with matter.

options.label: D
options.text: The energy of light does not relate to its interaction with matter.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the speaker's discussion about the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: The universe is a vast, empty space.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe is a vast, complex system that gives off the full spectrum of light.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe is a small, simple system that only gives off visible light.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe is a system that only gives off ultraviolet light.

multiple-choice.question: How can we study the light of a distant star or galaxy?

options.label: A
options.text: By using a telescope that can see only visible light.

options.label: B
options.text: By using a telescope that can see the full spectrum of light.

options.label: C
options.text: By using a device that can detect the energy of the light.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a device that can detect the frequency of the light.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the speaker's discussion about perception?

options.label: A
options.text: Perception is only related to what we can see with our eyes.

options.label: B
options.text: Perception is related to what we can experience and study in the natural world.

options.label: C
options.text: Perception is only related to what we can touch and feel.

options.label: D
options.text: Perception is only related to what we can hear and smell.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Decreasing the use of renewable energy

options.label: D

title: What are stem cells? - Craig A. Kohn

multiple-choice.question: What are the odds that two people are listening to the exact same playlist?
What do stem cells have the potential to become?

options.label: C
options.text: All other kinds of cells in the body

options.label: D
options.text: Neither skin cells nor muscle cells

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of stem cell researchers?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop new treatments for diseases

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how the body works

options.label: A
options.text: A form of cancer that affects the bone marrow

options.label: B
options.text: A form of cancer that affects the skin

options.label: C
options.text: A disease that affects the blood

options.label: D
options.text: A virus that affects the immune system

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the cells inside your bone marrow in leukemia?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They become healthy and function normally

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To create new blood cells for the patient's body

options.label: C
options.text: To replace the damaged cells in the bone marrow

options.label: D
options.text: To cure the disease and create new blood cells for the patient's body

multiple-choice.question: What are the three main types of stem cells used for medical treatments and research?

options.label: A

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What can scientists use stem cells to help understand?

options.label: B

multiple-choice.question: What is the long-term goal of stem cell research?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop a cure for all diseases

options.label: B

options.label: D

title: Origins of religion

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people learn through their experiences?

options.label: A
options.text: The difference between what poisoned them and what satisfied their hunger

options.label: B
options.text: The difference between good and evil

options.label: C
options.text: The difference between life and death

options.label: D
options.text: The difference between magic and reality

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe would happen if they ate the flesh of a strong beast?

options.label: A
options.text: The body had lost its strength

options.label: D
options.text: The spirit had left the body

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe was the source of movement in the world?

options.label: C
options.text: To show respect for the dead

options.label: D
options.text: To help preserve the spirit of the deceased

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe was the cause of lightning, thunder, and rain?

What did hunter-gatherers believe about the world?

options.label: A
options.text: That it was perfect as it was

options.label: B
options.text: That it was created by gods

options.label: C
options.text: That it was the result of chance

options.label: D
options.text: That it was the result of human progress

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what limited the imagination of those who had a biological potential for genius and those of normal intelligence?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: D
